Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto pitched five scoreless innings in Game 5 of the NLDS against the San Diego Padres.
Fernando Tatis Jr. hit into a double play to end the third inning.
Kiké Hernández hit a home run to give the Dodgers a 1-0 lead.
Yoshinobu Yamamoto retired six consecutive batters after the third inning.
Shohei Ohtani celebrated Yamamoto's performance by pouring sparkling wine on him.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers decided to start Yoshinobu Yamamoto in Game 5 because they figured their relievers couldn’t pitch the entire game.
Yamamoto was on the same six-day cycle on which he was kept in the regular season.
The Dodgers thought they could rely on Yamamoto due to his resiliency.
Manager Dave Roberts highlighted Yamamoto's international experience as a motivating factor.
The game featured two Japanese starters, Yamamoto and Yu Darvish, and was broadcast live in Japan.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers controlling owner Mark Walter praised Yamamoto for his gutsy performance.
Yamamoto credited his teammates for their support and encouragement.
Kiké Hernández emphasized Yamamoto's greatness and the reason for the Dodgers' investment in him.
Shohei Ohtani described Yamamoto's pitching as overwhelming.
Yamamoto joked about the alcohol getting into him through his skin during the celebration.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Yoshinobu Yamamoto's performance in Game 5 helped the Dodgers advance to the NL Championship Series.
Yamamoto's adjustment to the major leagues was delayed by a shoulder injury that sidelined him for three months.
The Dodgers worked with Yamamoto on the positioning of his glove between starts to avoid tipping pitches.
